repo.name: requests-credssp
repo.description: An authentication handler for using CredSSP with Python Requests.

readme.summary: Well-structured documentation with excellent installation instructions and configuration details, but lacks a complete quick start example and has a truncated message encryption example.
readme.top_issue: The message encryption example at the end is incomplete/truncated, leaving users without a working example for that feature

common_complaints: CredSSP authentication failures after version 2.0.0 upgrade
Unhelpful error messages that don't indicate root cause
Compatibility issues with specific Windows Server versions (2008, 2012R2, 2019)
Issues persist across multiple years without resolution
sentiment.summary: The project shows significant abandonment with recurring CredSSP authentication failures spanning 2018-2023, unresponsive maintainers, and critical issues remaining open without fixes or meaningful engagement.

concerns: No commits for over 2.5 years (since May 2023)
No activity on issues or PRs in the past 6 months
No recent releases or maintenance activity
No active contributors in past 6 months
positive_signals: Repository still exists and is not archived
Some historical maintenance before the stall
maintenance.summary: Package is stale with no maintenance activity for over 2.5 years despite having unresolved open issues.

project_metrics.description: An authentication handler for using CredSSP with Python Requests.

readme.summary: Well-structured README with excellent installation instructions and basic examples, but lacks comprehensive configuration documentation and troubleshooting guidance.

common_complaints: Limited feature set for network mocking (HAR replay not supported)
Lack of documentation for non-standard environments (distrobox/containerized setups)
Verbose syntax for common operations (text extraction, element presence checks)

readme.summary: Clear purpose and installation instructions, but severely lacking practical usage examples and configuration guidance for end users.
readme.top_issue: No quick start code example showing basic database connection or query usage - the README is 90% focused on development/hacking rather than using the package

common_complaints: Connection pooling issues with cloud databases (RDS Proxy connection pinning)
Timeout handling inconsistencies between psycopg2 and psycopg3
Missing features requiring workarounds or duplicate configuration
Async/pool lifecycle management complexity
Performance bottlenecks in Python layer
praise_themes: Well-structured codebase with extensive type annotations
Active development and feature requests being considered
Good documentation references (Rust prior art, PostgreSQL docs)
sentiment.summary: Psycopg shows healthy community engagement with active maintenance, but users face migration friction from psycopg2 and encounter nuanced issues around connection pooling, async patterns, and cloud database compatibility that require maintainer attention.

injection_risks.description: Potential SQL injection risk due to the use of user input in the scramble_caching_sha2 function without proper sanitization.

Lack of input validation for sensitive parameters such as password and public key.

repo.name: port-for
repo.description: `port-for` is a command-line utility and a python library that helps with local TCP ports managment. `port-for <foo>` script finds an unused port and associates it with `<foo>`. Subsequent calls will return the same port number.
